intro: Satureja calamintha var. hirta, commonly known as hairy woodruff, is a perennial herb native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant features small, white or pale blue flowers that bloom in terminal clusters, typically from late spring to early summer. Its leaves are lance-shaped, hairy, and have a strong, mint-like fragrance. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or woodland areas.
